subject: Check object segment MD5s
commit_message:
Check object segment MD5s

Now if a client is downloading a large object and one of the segment
fetches gets bad data, we'll abort the request right away instead of
letting the client carry on. We do this by checking each segment's
body against the etag in the GET response's headers, like we tell
clients to do.

To make sure that the etag is the MD5, we add ?multipart-manifest=get
to all segment GET requests. That way, a segment won't be another
large object, because a large object's etag isn't its MD5. This does
mean that clients can't make, say, a DLO manifest that points to a
bunch of SLO manifests. However, that capability was only introduced
in Swift 1.13.0 (post-Havana); prior to that, clients couldn't mix
large-object types. I'm more than happy to trade that capability away
in exchange for data-integrity checks.

Change-Id: I98c78a291ee1a863a36d54a22867bd01c126644e

subject: Make the container replicator notice misplaced objects
commit_message:
Make the container replicator notice misplaced objects

If replication is attempted between two container DBs that have
different storage policy indices, then the older DB wins. When this
happens, all the objects in the newer DB are enqueued for
reconciliation.

This only happens on the sender (replicator) side of container
replication; on the receiver (container server) side, a 409 response
is returned. We can't go enqueue things on the receiver side because
it might take a really long time, and that's a bad idea to do in the
middle of servicing an HTTP request.

subject: User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects
commit_message:
User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects

In an HA deployment, a 60 seconds delay between reconnects can be quite
problematic. This patch changes the delay calculation by setting the max
delay to 5s and by changing the way it is increased.

Unfortunately, this is one of the places where both our main drivers are
not consistent. Rabbit's driver uses configuration parameters for this
whereas qpid's driver has never had one. However, I would prefer not
adding configuration paremeters to qpid's driver for the following
reasons:

    1. Most of OpenStack services depend on the messaging layer, hence
    they need it to be available. A 5s delay seems to be reasonable and
    I could argue the need of tune it further. Although so frequent
    reconnects can add load to the network, that wouldn't be the main
    issue if one of the brokers go down.
    2. We're trying to move away from configuration options towards using
    transport URL. This path is still not clear and I would
    prefer avoiding adding new options until we clear it out.

Closes-bug: #1281148

subject: Allow applications using keystoneclient to close connexions.
commit_message:
Allow applications using keystoneclient to close connexions.

Adding close() method to HTTPClient and Session classes, in order for
applications using python-keystoneclient to be able to close HTTP
connexions that aren't useful anymore.

Once this fix has been accepted, Horizon has to be updated to close
unused clients, in order to fix bug 1282089.

Usage exemple:

In a Python shell:
    >>> from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client
    >>> keystone = client.Client(username="admin",
    ...                          password="password",
    ...                          tenant_name="admin",
    ...                          auth_url="http://localhost:5000/v2.0")
    >>> keystone.users.list()
    [<User ...>]
    >>> keystone.tenants.list()
    [<Tenant ...>]

In a shell terminal, on the same machine:
    $ lsof -p 6968 | grep TCP
    python  6968 ubuntu    3u  IPv4 18392267      0t0
        TCP localhost:59504->localhost:5000 (ESTABLISHED)
    python  6968 ubuntu    4u  IPv4 18391370      0t0
        TCP 84.39.34.140:43831->84.39.34.140:35357 (ESTABLISHED)
    $

In the Python shell:
    >>> keystone.close()
    >>>

In the terminal:
    $ lsof -p 6968 | grep TCP
    $

Or In Python:
    with client.Client(username="admin",
    ...                password="password",
    ...                tenant_name="admin",
    ...                auth_url="http://localhost:5000/v2.0") as keystone:
    ...     keystone.tenants.list()
    ...
    [<Tenant ...>]
    >>>

In the terminal:
    $ lsof -p 6968 | grep TCP
    $

In unit tests, resource contextmanagers such as network(), subnet()
try to delete themselves after returning from yield even if an
exception occurs. However when an exception occurs, there is a case
where deletion fails. In this case original exception will be hidden
and it makes difficult to debug test failures.

recreated, so there is no need to try to delete resources even
when an exception occurs. This commit removes try-finally clause
from resource contextmanagers to make original errors visible.

commit_message:
Restore image status on duplicate image upload

Glance should not allow already uploaded images to be modified by
another upload. Currently, when configured with the local filesystem
backend, Glance prevents duplicate upload of an already uploaded image
BUT it changes the image status to "saving".

This commit adds a status transition state machine to the domain.Image
class and modifies the domain.Image.status setter function to verify
status transitions based on this state machine - only target states that
can be reached from the image's current state are permitted.

Tests have also been agumented to verify that the original image (meta)
data does not change in case of a conflicting upload.

        glance/domain/__init__.py
        glance/tests/functional/v2/test_images.py
        glance/tests/unit/test_cache_middleware.py

subject: Add fixed and floating IPs discovery via neutron

Add fixed and floating IPs discovery via neutron

  don't have allocated floating IP or/and fixed IP in the

     * Get fixed or/and floating ips addresses from FloatingIP resource

subject: Remove .gitreview
commit_message:
Remove .gitreview

This probably needs some explanation.

There are two ways projects get into the OpenStack gerrit
infrastructure.

a) They are declared in openstack-infra/config with an upstream ref.
b) They are declared without an upstream ref.

In (a) .gitreview is incorrect for a cookiecutter cut project - the
project cannot be used with gerrit until it is in the system, and
until the review is approved and actioned the contents of .gitreview
cannot be determined.

In (b) the openstack-infra new project automation creates a correct
.gitreview automatically, which causes pushing the new project
contents to error, as the contents of .gitreview differ (due to no
trailing \n in the cookiecutter output).

So, it seems to me that in both cases we're better served by not
including .gitreview in cookiecutter.

subject: User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects

User a more accurate max_delay for reconnects

In an HA deployment, a 60 seconds delay between reconnects can be quite
problematic. This patch changes the delay calculation by setting the max
delay to 5s and by changing the way it is increased.

Unfortunately, this is one of the places where both our main drivers are
not consistent. Rabbit's driver uses configuration parameters for this
whereas qpid's driver has never had one. However, I would prefer not
adding configuration paremeters to qpid's driver for the following
reasons:

    1. Most of OpenStack services depend on the messaging layer, hence
    they need it to be available. A 5s delay seems to be reasonable and
    I could argue the need of tune it further. Although so frequent
    reconnects can add load to the network, that wouldn't be the main
    issue if one of the brokers go down.
    2. We're trying to move away from configuration options towards using
    transport URL. This path is still not clear and I would

commit_message:
Properly handle unicode & utf-8 in LDAP

This patch adds all the necessary type conversions between the LDAP
API's.

* string literals are unicode

* unicode strings are utf-8 encoded before calling LDAP

* utf-8 strings received from the LDAP API are decoded into unicode

* string classes use the six.text_type for Python 2 vs. Python 3
  compatibility

* the fake LDAP implementation was reworked such that it's external
  API only handles UTF-8 encoded strings but only uses unicode
  internally. This is because internally it must be able to operate on
  logical characters in order to perform string operations on it's
  data. This is very much akin to what happens in a real LDAP
  implementation, the interface is UTF-8 but operations occur on
